Mr. Motian isn't part of the music's backing: he helped create the aesthetic possibility for it. His drumming is calm and thoughtful, open and unprogrammed; it tries to come up with something new in each bar while retaining a groove. And much of the same spirit can be heard in Mr. McHenry's playing, with the rhythm and harmony of bebop while generally operating in spacey rubato time. Mr. McHenry likes strong, slow melodies; he bends notes with a kind of radical plaintiveness, jumping large intervals in one curving sigh. Sets through Sunday at 9 and 11 p.m., with a 12:30 set tomorrow; cover charge is $30.  RATLIFF    FRANK MORGAN QUARTET, Jazz Standard, 116 East 27th Street, Manhattan, (212) 576-2232. Like many other musicians who discovered Charlie Parker when they were just a little too young to be professionals, Mr. Morgan heard bebop as a sacred text. And he still has a remarkably beautiful way with it, presenting it as classical constructions in medium tempo. Set through Sunday at 7:30 and 9:30 p.m., with an 11:30 set tonight and tomorrow; cover charge is $25, $20 on Sunday.  RATLIFF    'ONE FOR TRANE,' Sista's Place, 456 Nostrand Avenue, at Jefferson Avenue, Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, (718) 398-1766. A tribute to John Coltrane by musicians who worked with him or were influenced by him: the saxophonists Sonny Fortune and Odean Pope; the pianist John Hicks; the bassist Reggie Workman; and the drummer Rashied Ali. Tomorrow night at 9 and 10:30; cover charge is $20.  RATLIFF    MATANA ROBERTS QUARTET, Jazz Gallery, 290 Hudson Street, South Village, (212) 242-1063. A young saxophonist from Chicago who has demonstrated an interest in jazz from Ellington to Ornette Coleman and beyond, to dub and Afrobeat, Ms. Roberts has a growing reputation in New York. She plays with a band including the trumpeter Taylor Ho Bynum, the bassist Tarus Mateen and the drummer Tomas Fujiwara. Sets are tonight at 9 and 10:30; admission is $15 per set.  RATLIFF    * 'VISION CLUB': ROB BROWN STONE HOUSE TRIO, MAT MANERI TRIO, Brunstein Showroom, 13 Stanton Street, between Bowery and Chrystie, Lower East Side, (212) 696-6681; on the Web, it is visionfestival.org. A new concert series continues, creating different pairings within experimental jazz. The alto saxophonist Rob Brown improvises clearly, with a bright tone, and a lot of imagination; Mat Maneri, the violinist, creates an environment of wicked calm and unpredictability. Both are among the better bandleaders in the New York free-jazz scene. Tomorrow at 8 (Mr. Brown); at 10 (Mr. Maneri); admission is $15.  RATLIFF    BEN WALTZER GROUP, Cornelia Street Cafe, 29 Cornelia Street, West Village, (212) 989-9319. A no-nonsense young jazz pianist in the Ellington and Monk vein, Mr. Waltzer gets a big, ringing sound out of the extreme registers of the instrument; his recent album, ''100 Dreams Ago'' (Fresh Sound), shows a focused bandleader. Music starts tonight at 8:30; cover charge is $10.  RATLIFF    Cabaret    A selective listing by critics of The Times: New or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show. Full reviews of recent cabaret shows: nytimes.com/music.    BARBARA CARROLL, Oak Room, Algonquin Hotel, 59 West 44th Street, (212) 419-9331. The Lady of a Thousand Songs is back in the Oak Room for Sunday brunch and evening performances. This elegant, red-headed pianist and singer is a poised entertainer whose impeccable pianism belongs to the school of jazz that maintains a sense of classical decorum at the keyboard. Even when swinging out, she remains an impressionist with special affinities for Thelonious Monk and bossa nova. Vocally, she belongs to the conversational tradition of Mabel Mercer with a style that's blasé but never cold. Sunday at 2 and 8 p.m. Cover: $55 at 2, including brunch at noon; $80 at 8, with dinner served at 6:30.  STEPHEN HOLDEN    MELISSA MANCHESTER, Feinstein's at the Regency, Regency Hotel, 540 Park Avenue, at 61st Street, (212) 339-4095. The one-time reigning diva of Arista Records has adopted a back-to-basics approach to her music, toning down her brassiness to reach back to her early days as a smoky voiced singer-songwriter. Old hits like ''Come In From the Rain'' and ''Don't Cry Out Loud'' are revisited in a quieter mode. Her voice, unfortunately, is considerably the worse for wear. And new songs that aspire to take a longer, deeper view of life and love are marred by lyrics that reduce honest sentiments to greeting-card banalities. Tonight and tomorrow night at 8:30 and 11. Cover: $60; $40 minimum at the early shows, $30 for the late shows.  HOLDEN    BOBBY SHORT, Cafe Carlyle, Carlyle Hotel, 35 East 76th Street, (212) 570-7189. After announcing his semi-retirement last year from performing at the Cafe Carlyle, this legendary singer and pianist changed his mind and is back in action for another season. Mr. Short never fails to conjure ebullient party spirits and has impeccable taste in songs. Expect to hear at least one of his three signature songs, ''Guess Who's in Town?,'' ''Just One of Those Things'' and ''Romance in the Dark,'' along with something by one of the two Dukes (Ellington and Vernon). Tonight and tomorrow night at 8:45 and 10:45. Cover: $95.  HOLDEN    * PAULA WEST AND THE ERIC REED TRIO, Oak Room, Algonquin Hotel, 59 West 44th Street, (212) 419-9331. This San Francisco jazz singer has always relished transgressing stylistic conventions. Her new show includes a folk-jazz-rap version of Bob Dylan's ''Subterranean Homesick Blues,'' which she turns into a slurred mouthful of pure jazz rhythm. Her mischievous streak also asserts itself in slyly updated versions of Cole Porter's ''At Long Last Love'' and ''Anything Goes,'' that mention phenomena like nonfat creamer, the Hilton sisters and reality television. Her thoughtful renditions of ''Stormy Weather'' and ''Black and Blue'' find her emerging as a heavyweight balladeer. Tonight and tomorrow night at 9 and 11:30. Cover: $50; $40 prix fixe dinner at the early shows, $20 minimum at the late shows.  HOLDEN    Classical    A selective listing by critics of The Times: New or noteworthy opera and classical music events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region. * denotes a highly recommended event. Full reviews of recent classical music and opera performances:  nytimes.com/music.    Opera    'AIDA' The Metropolitan Opera often succeeds in making a spectacle of itself; at least the spectacle is warranted in Verdi's ''Aida,'' which was originally conceived as grand opera. Everyone involved in the current revival can more or less make the thing fly, led by Dolora Zajick as an Amneris whose ringing mezzo threatens to blow everyone else offstage, the excellent Marcello Viotti in the pit, and, when he's on, Eduardo Villa as a ringing Radamès. Anooshah Golesorkhi is a valiant Amonasro, but isn't really a Verdi baritone, and the role of Aida is a couple of sizes too large for Fiorenza Cedolins. Still, add a few armies of dancers and horses and you could have a fine old time. Tomorrow afternoon at 1:30, Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center, (212) 362-6000. Remaining tickets: $145 to $215.  ANNE MIDGETTE    'LA BOHÈME' Ruth Anne Swenson is the fresh face in the cast of this Puccini favorite, which has returned to the Met in Franco Zeffirelli's outsize production. Ms. Swenson is well-known to opera fans for her beautifully nimble coloratura soprano, but she has recently been exploring more dramatic spinto roles, singing her first ever Mimi at the Met last month. She held her own at that performance, though she sounded underpowered next to the booming tenor of Marcelo Álvarez. Elsewhere in the cast, Peter Mattei sings an impressive Marcello, with rich, deep colors in his baritone. Daniel Oren conducts. Tonight at 8, Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center, (212) 362-6000. Tickets: $35 to $200.  JEREMY EICHLER    'CAVALLERIA RUSTICANA' AND 'PAGLIACCI' Opera's favorite double bill returns tomorrow night in the Metropolitan Opera's venerable productions of Mascagni's ''Cavalleria Rusticana'' and Leoncavallo's ''Pagliacci.'' Go not for a famous cast but for Mascagni's lightning-bolt blood and guts and Leoncavallo's equally sinister exercise in revenge and murder. Dennis Russell Davies conducts both operas. Tomorrow night at 8, Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center, (212) 362-6000. Remaining tickets: $215.  BERNARD HOLLAND    'HAROUN AND THE SEA OF STORIES' The New York City Opera, already having one of its best seasons in years, is presenting the world premiere of a major opera by Charles Wuorinen, the unabashedly rigorous American modernist composer. Give Mr. Wuorinen credit for sensing the operatic possibilities of Salman Rushdie's enchanting and timely 1990 novel for children. The story, a parable about the importance of the imagination, tells of a young boy, Haroun, the son of a famed story-teller who has lost his gift of gab, and Haroun's daring adventure to the Sea of Stories, where the boy defeats the Prince of Silence and reconnects his father's mental pipeline to the sources of imagination in the magical sea. James Fenton has streamlined and adapted the novel into one of the best librettos in some time. Mark Lamos's colorful and playful production works beautifully. But Mr. Wuorinen's formidable score, though it has brilliant strokes, overwhelms the drama and the challenging vocal lines with unremittingly complex undercurrents of skittish atonal orchestral music. The soprano Heather Buck brings tomboyish energy and a bright, agile voice to the title role. George Manahan draws a confident and vibrant performance from the cast and orchestra. Tomorrow at 1:30 p.m., New York State Theater, Lincoln Center, (212) 870-5570. Tickets: $32 to $115.  ANTHONY TOMMASINI    'LE NOZZE DI FIGARO' Though the New York City Opera may garner the most attention for its adventurous productions of operas from the 20th century and the Baroque era, the company can also do extremely well by the standard repertory, as with its current revival of Mozart's ''Nozze di Figaro.'' The 1977 production, with period sets and costumes, is still pleasant and effective. What counts, though, is the cast and this one is delightful. The Israeli soprano Sharon Rostorf-Zamir, in her company debut, makes a sweet-toned, lyrical and endearingly plucky Susanna. The strapping and robust-voiced bass-baritone David Pittsinger towers over her as Figaro, and sparks fly between them. Jennifer Rivera brings her dusky mezzo-soprano voice and impish stage presence to the role of the hormonal page Cherubino. Paulo Szot and Orla Boylan as the Count and Countess Almaviva are also standouts. And Steven Mosteller conducts a lithe and articulate performance. I was not prepared for this revival to be so good. Tomorrow night at 8, New York State Theater, Lincoln Center, (212) 870-5570. Tickets: $32 to $115.  TOMMASINI    'LA TRAVIATA' Verdi's drama is so well written that a singer who can manage to get through the difficult title role is virtually guaranteed a success. At City Opera, Maria Kanyova attacks Violetta with a will and negotiates the role's hurdles with a kind of fierce vivacity, down to a brief but solid high E-flat at the end of ''Sempre libera'' in Act I. Since the start of this revival in September, she's been joined by some new men in her life: Grant Youngblood, who should be a fine strong Germont, and Eric Fennell as Alfredo. Atsushi Yamada conducts these two final performances of the run. Tonight at 8 and Sunday afternoon at 1:30, New York State Theater, Lincoln Center, (212) 870-5570. Tickets: $27 to $105 tonight, $32 to $105 on Sunday.  MIDGETTE    Classical Music    BARGEMUSIC The concerts on the barge tomorrow night and Sunday are intriguing, less for the repertory per se (Tchaikovsky, Prokofiev and Miaskovsky) than for the ensemble: the Kopelman Quartet in its New York debut. The group's leader, the Ukrainian violinist Mikhail Kopelman, left the Tokyo String Quartet in 2002 after mutual recognition that his own distinctly Slavic approach diverged too greatly from that of his Japanese and British colleagues. Reversing course, Mr. Kopelman has now assembled a quartet of players with identical backgrounds, having all trained together at the Moscow Conservatory in the 1970's. The homogeneity promises better chemistry, and, at a time when the personnel of many ensembles is more diverse than ever, it makes for a fascinating case study in the limits of musical globalization. Rounding out the weekend's programming, the violinist Mark Peskanov and the pianist Katya Mihailova will play Schubert this evening. Tonight and tomorrow night at 7:30 and Sunday afternoon at 4, Fulton Ferry Landing, under the Brooklyn Bridge, Brooklyn, (718) 624-2083. Tickets: $35; students, $25.  EICHLER    CHAMBER MUSIC SOCIETY OF LINCOLN CENTER David Finckel and Wu Han, the new directors of the Chamber Music Society, speak of curating music rather than programming it; and although they didn't actually program this season, the trio of trios that's on offer on Sunday afternoon has a museumlike aspect, in the best sense. If you want repertory staples in a reliable performance, this is a place to go: three trios by three classical masters (Beethoven, Mendelssohn and Brahms), performed by two ever-reliable artist members of the Society -- Anne-Marie McDermott, the pianist, and Fred Sherry, the cellist -- as well as the violinist Jennifer Frautschi. Sunday at 5 p.m. and Tuesday at 7:30 p.m., Alice Tully Hall, Lincoln Center, (212) 875-5788. Tickets: $27.50 to $48.  MIDGETTE    ESART TRIO BERLIN Carnegie Hall continues the Distinctive Debuts series and its accompanying exchange program with the European music establishment by presenting the Esart Trio Berlin tonight. Music by the contemporary German composer Wolfgang Rihm should be an item of interest. There is also the more familiar repertory from Beethoven and Dvorak. At 7:30 p.m., Weill Recital Hall, Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800. Tickets: $24.  HOLLAND    TANIA LEÓN As part of its important Composer Portraits series, Miller Theater is offering an overview of the music of Tania León, in performances by Mosaic, a new-music ensemble, as well as guests (including the composer, who will conduct). Ms. León, who was born in Havana in 1943, writes feisty music that takes Latin, gospel and jazz influences into account but is decidedly in the art music tradition. Among the works to be performed are ''A la Par,''  ''Indígena,''  ''Sin Normas Ajenas,''  ''Canto'' and the New York premiere of ''Azulejos.'' Tonight at 8 (there is a pre-concert discussion at 7), Miller Theater, Columbia University, Broadway at 116th Street, (212) 854-7799. Tickets: $20.  ALLAN KOZINN    PARTHENIA John Dowland's ''Lachrimae,'' a piece with a regretful, descending melodic line meant to suggest the falling of tears, achieved an extraordinary popularity among the melancholy Elizabethans. Having published the work as a song (''Flow My Tears'') and as a virtuosic lute solo, Dowland revisited his hit in 1604, this time using it as the basis for seven pavans, each expressing a different quality of dolefulness. When he published this cycle, as ''Lachrimae, or Seven Tears,'' Dowland added a selection of shorter, brighter dances as well. Parthenia, the surperb viol consort, is joining forces with the lutenist Paul O'Dette to celebrate the 400th anniversary of this collection. Mr. O'Dette is a magnificent Dowland interpreter, and Parthenia's sound (augmented here by John Mark Rozendaal) has the right darkness and heft for the music. Tonight at 8, Corpus Christi Church, 529 West 121st Street, Morningside Heights, (212) 358-5942. Tickets: $25, $18 for students and 65+.  KOZINN    SUSANNA PHILLIPS The Marilyn Horne Foundation knows how to keep young singers on the map. Susanna Phillips, a soprano from Alabama who holds two degrees from the Juilliard School, was presented in a duo recital by the foundation a couple of years ago and returns on Sunday for her own solo turn, in songs by Schubert, Enescu, Schumann, Poulenc and Walton, accompanied by the pianist Carol Wong. Sunday afternoon at 3, St. Bartholemew's Church, Park Avenue at 51st Street, (212) 378-0248. Tickets: $20, $15 for 65+, free for students.  MIDGETTE    RIVERSIDE SYMPHONY Some orchestras, but not enough of them, have a composer in residence. The Riverside Symphony is actually run by a composer, its artistic director Anthony Korf, along with the conductor George Rothman. This is one reason that the orchestra, with its strong roster of players, consistently presents such well-conceived and adventurous programs. Tonight's concert, the first of the Riverside Symphony's 24th season, offers works for string orchestra. Dvorak's miraculously scored and wistfully tuneful Serenade should contrast effectively with the New York premiere of Erwin Schulhoff's Three Pieces. Though the Prague-born Schulhoff was pronounced a prodigy by Dvorak his life was cut short when he perished in a Nazi concentration camp in 1942. A more recent work completes the program: Keith Lay's ''On the Playground,'' which features the violinist Cenovia Cummins, the Riverside Symphony's fine concertmaster, as soloist. Tonight at 8, Alice Tully Hall, Lincoln Center, (212) 721-6500. Tickets: $25 to $45.  TOMMASINI    CHARLES ROSEN One of the keyboard world's more thoughtful, intellectual players, Charles Rosen is as renowned for his insightful books and essays as for his probing performances. But his playing is by no means bookish: as concerned as he is with the details of style and structure, he is also intent on showing composers as creatures of flesh and blood, animated by passions, desires, victories and disappointments. In the finale of his three-part series, ''The Romantic Generation'' -- the title comes from one of his books -- Mr. Rosen is examining the music of Mendelssohn and Brahms, with a particular focus on their fusing of Classical and Romantic sensibilities. Sunday at 1:30 p.m. (a lecture) and 3 (the recital), 92nd Street Y, 1395 Lexington Avenue, (212) 415-5500. Tickets: $30.  KOZINN    RICHARD STOLTZMAN He is one of the very few clarinetists with a high-profile career as an orchestral soloist, but Richard Stoltzman has also remained deeply devoted to chamber music. Last month at Weill Recital Hall, he gave a sincere and generously expressive performance of a Mozart trio. For this recital, he is joined by the pianist Jeremy Denk in standard repertory by Schubert, Schumann, Berg and Brahms as well as the New York premiere of a work by Yehudi Wyner. Tomorrow at 8 p.m., 92nd Street Y, 1395 Lexington Avenue, (212) 415-5500. Tickets: $35.  EICHLER    Dance    A selective listing by critics of The Times: New or noteworthy dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region. * denotes a highly recommended event. Full reviews of recent dance performances:  nytimes.com/dance.    AMERICAN BALLET THEATER The company's festive autumn season, which has featured works of many kinds -- dramatic and abstract, serious and comic -- closes Sunday night. Tonight at 8, tomorrow at 2 and 8 p.m., Sunday at 2 and 7:30 p.m., City Center, 131 West 55th Street, Manhattan, (212) 581-1212. Tickets: $35 to $85.  JACK ANDERSON    IVY BALDWIN The wildly imaginative Ms. Baldwin has conjured up a scarily nutty world in her new ''Now Leaving Vanderville.'' Citizens go to war only on Mondays. (Well, that doesn't sound too bad.) They also stuff ducks for a living, however, as they wait patiently to be annihilated every week. All this is set to a score of songs by Kurt Weill, performed live by Franz Nicolay and Carrie Lewis. Also on the program is ''la table,'' a duet for snobs. Tonight and tomorrow (and Thursday through next Saturday) at 8 p.m., Dixon Place, 258 Bowery, between Prince and Houston Streets, Lower East Side, (212) 219-0736 or www.dixonplace.org. Tickets: $10 and $15.  JENNIFER DUNNING    BLAK TINO PERFORMANCE SERIES Things are getting complicated in the world of ethnic nomenclature. This series, for instance, celebrates art by black, Latino and ''Blatino'' artists. The choreographers for this first of two weekends are Richard Rivera, Afua Hall, Cesar Abreu and Christopher Campbell. No word as to which category each belongs to, but Mr. Rivera and his Physual troupe are longtime presences on the South Bronx dance scene, and Ms. Hall stood out as a quietly powerful performer in recent Manhattan performances. Tonight and tomorrow at 8 p.m., BAAD! (The Bronx Academy of Arts and Dance), 841 Barretto Street, Hunts Point, South Bronx, (718) 842-5223. Tickets: $15.  DUNNING    * CHARLES DENNIS: 'HOMECOMING' This documentary celebrates 20 years of dance and ultimate funk at P.S. 122, of which Mr. Dennis is a co-founder. The film focuses on 10 choreographers who created seminal work there, with music by John Zorn, photography by Dona Ann McAdams and commentary by presenters and critics who include Mark Russell, for many years the theater's director and animating spirit. Sunday (and next Sunday) at 2 p.m., P.S. 122, 150 First Avenue, at Ninth Street, East Village, (212) 477-5288. Tickets: $5.  DUNNING    'FOREVER TANGO' Better than Viagra, and for all ages, too. Luis Bravo's ''Forever Tango'' features sultry and comical dancers and first-rate musicians in a show, extended through Nov. 28, that is both tacky and transcendent. Tonight (and Tuesdays and Thursdays) at 8 p.m.; tomorrow (and Wednesdays) at 2 and 8 p.m.; Sundays at 3 p.m. Shubert Theater, 225 West 44th Street, Manhattan, (212) 239-6200. Tickets: $45 to $85.  DUNNING    * MARC BAMUTHI JOSEPH There's buzz. He's said to be cool. And Mr. Joseph and his new ''Word Becomes Flesh'' should probably be seen, in this New York debut, for a lot of other reasons, too. Among them is his status as a featured artist in Russell Simmons's HBO Def Poetry Jam series, a National Poetry Slam Champion and a Broadway-musical child performer who became a producer of work by the next generation. Most of all, there is the piece itself. A series of letters to his unborn son, Joseph, ''Flesh'' combines music, poetry, visuals, hip-hop, tap and modern and West African dance to document a pregnancy from the point of view of a young single father. Tonight and tomorrow night at 7:30, Dance Theater Workshop, 219 West 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 924-0077 or www.dtw.org. Tickets: $20.  DUNNING    MANDANCE PROJECT Eliot Feld's new choreographic endeavor brings together five men (Damian Woetzel, Wu-Kang Chen, Nickemil Concepcion, Jason Jordan and Sean Suozzi) and one woman (Patricia Tuthill) in solos, duets and group works by Mr. Feld to music ranging from Bach to jug band tunes. Tonight and tomorrow night at 8; tomorrow at 2 and Sunday at 3 p.m. Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 242-0800. Tickets: $42; matinees, $25 for adults, $15 for children.  ANDERSON    MEXICO HERE: MEXICAN CHOREOGRAPHERS IN NEW YORK You may not be able to go home again. But you can't ever really leave home, even when you move on to faraway New York. That is a premise of this program, in which five young Mexican choreographers now living in New York -- Geraldine Cardiel, Penelope Gonzalez, Ricardo Gomez, David Matiano, Gabriela Medina and Erick Montes -- will present dances set to composers who include Carlo Nicolau, as part of a monthlong citywide celebration of Mexican arts. Tonight at 8; Sunday at 2 p.m., Skirball Center, New York University, 566 La Guardia Place, south of Washington Square South, Greenwich Village, (212) 992-8484. Tickets: $20.  DUNNING    HIMIKO MINATO & DANCERS Ms. Minato trained in Tokyo before coming to New York in 1997 to study at the Merce Cunningham Studio and perform with Jeanette Stoner. In her new ''Yellow,'' which explores the attainability of the American dream, Ms. Minato draws on principles of Japanese Buddhism to counter American expectations of ''yellow'' or Asian people. Tonight through Sunday at 8 p.m. Joyce SoHo, 155 Mercer Street, (212) 334-7479. Tickets: $15; $12 for students and 65+.  DUNNING    NIBROLL This Tokyo-based multidisciplinary collective will perform its ''Dry Flower,'' a full-evening piece in which street action, drifting petals and stampeding gazelles share the stage. The work is new, and Japanese modern-dance and performance art is generally unpredictable but usually thought-provoking and often filled with crude but delicious humor. For the record, the dance is by Mikuni Yanaihara, the founder of the troupe in 1997. Today at noon and 8 p.m.; tomorrow at 8 p.m, the Kitchen, 512 West 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 255-5793 x 11 or www.thekitchen.org. Tickets: $20; $16 for students and 65+; $10 for today's lunch-break program.  DUNNING    JEREMY NELSON A triple bill of recently choreographed works includes ''Accent Elimination,'' based on the different ways people may speak or move; ''Bridge of Fools,'' a trio, and ''SightUnseen,'' a dance inspired by traffic patterns. Tonight, tomorrow and Sunday at 8:30 p.m., Danspace Project, St. Mark's Church, Second Avenue at 10th Street, East Village, (212) 674-8194. Tickets: $15.  ANDERSON    NEXT WAVE FESTIVAL: BALLET PRELJOCAJ A choreographer who defies easy classification returns to New York with ''Near Life Experience,'' an eveninglong production that explores how an instant of abandon -- be it a fainting spell, an ecstatic trance or an orgasm -- can invest corporeal realities with a sense of the transcendent. Tomorrow at 7:30 p.m., Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue, Fort Greene, (718) 636-4100. Tickets: $20 to $45. (Related review, Page 3.)  ANDERSON    * DANA SALISBURY The Bessie Award-winning Ms. Salisbury is known for dances and videos that are acutely conscious of the world around her and all of its details. In her new multimedia ''Whole-Body-Seer,'' whose title is drawn from a memoir about blindness written by John Hull, Ms. Salisbury explores the world of the blind, in terms of the senses and the imagination. Tonight and tomorrow at 8 p.m., University Settlement, 184 Eldridge Street, at Rivington Street, Lower East Side, (212) 929-8145. Tickets: $15.  DUNNING    * STREB S.L.A.M. You could say Elizabeth Streb and her performers are sitting pretty, with their own 150-seat studio-theater in which to create new work and regularly present it. But no one sits for long at a Streb program. The dancers fly, dive and dangle in new and recent pieces. The audience can walk around, as at a fairground, with popcorn provided. Tonight and tomorrow (and next Friday and Saturday) at 7 p.m., S.L.A.M. (Streb Lab for Action Mechanics), 51 North First Street, Williamsburg, Brooklyn, (718) 384-6491. Tickets: $15.  DUNNING    * SUNDAYS AT THREE: ALEXANDRA BELLER Ms. Beller, who danced with Bill T. Jones, is known as a lush and hurtling force of nature with a brain. In this informal free series, which combines performing and discussion, she and her company will perform dances about experiencing war and about whether we do actually exist. Sunday at 3 p.m., Harkness Dance Center, 92nd Street Y, 1395 Lexington Avenue, Manhattan. Information: (212) 415-5500. Tickets: $10.  DUNNING    * VIRSKY UKRAINIAN NATIONAL DANCE COMPANY This 85-member company of dancers and musicians, based in Kiev, has toured the world but somehow resisted becoming a tourist-office attraction. The show is sleekly staged, but the music and dance are genuinely rousing and colorful. Sunday at 2 p.m., Lehman Concert Hall, 250 Bedford Park Boulevard West, the Bronx, (718) 960-8833. Tickets: $20 to $35.  DUNNING    * WORLD MUSIC INSTITUTE: WHIRLING DERVISHES OF DAMASCUS Mesmerized and mesmerizing, the Dervishes are Sufi mystics, members of an order founded by the 13th-century Persian mystical poet Jalaluddin Rumi. Rumi believed in the ''spinning-off'' of worldly diversions to find unity with the divine. The company will be joined by Sheik Hamza Shakkur, a grand master of Muslim sacred song, and Al-Kindi, an ensemble devoted to classical Arab music. Tonight at 8:30, Zankel Hall, Carnegie Hall, (212) 545-7536. Tickets: $30 and $42.  DUNNING    Art    A selective listing by critics of The Times: New or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. At many museums, children under 12 and members are admitted free. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free unless noted. * denotes a highly recommended show. Full reviews of recent museum and gallery shows: nytimes.com/art.    Museums    'ADAPTIVE BEHAVIOR,' New Museum of Contemporary Art/Chelsea, 556 West 22nd Street, (212) 219-1222, through Nov. 13. Occupying new temporary quarters on the Chelsea Art Museum's ground floor, the New Museum presents a mostly video group show that reflects the problems of adapting to the constant changes of modern experience. Robert Melee's home-entertainment center documents his adaptation to his eccentric mother; a video by Bojan Sarcevic shows a Turkish Gypsy band learning to play Western pop songs; and, best of all, a video by Kerry Tribe shows a wonderfully charismatic 10-year-old girl thoughtfully responding to philosophical questions posed by a man off camera. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, noon to 6 p.m.; Thursdays, to 8 p.m. Admission: $6; students and 65+, $3.  KEN JOHNSON    * 'THE ART OF ROMARE BEARDEN,' Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, (212) 570-3600, through Jan. 9. It's a pity only that this retrospective is so big. Art like Bearden's -- mostly small, intense and intricate -- deserves close scrutiny. His genius, aside from his poetic knack for piecing scraps of photographs and other tiny tidbits together, was to see collage as an inherent social metaphor: that its essence was to turn nothings into something, making disparate elements cohere, a positivist enterprise. His collages celebrated black culture and personal history, combined elements of East and West, high and low, old and new: African masks with ancient Greek art, Matisse with patchwork quilts. Literature and music shaped the work no less than Picasso, George Grosz and Vermeer did. ''There are roads out of secret places within us along which we all must move as we go to touch others,'' Bearden said. And that's exactly where he takes us. Hours: Wednesdays, Thursdays, Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays, 1 to 9 p.m. Admission: $12; $9.50, students and 62+.  MICHAEL KIMMELMAN    * 'THE AZTEC EMPIRE,' Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 423-3500, through Feb. 13. When a big survey of Aztec art opened in London in 2002, everybody flipped out. It was one of the hottest ancient-art events since Tutankhamen. Now an expanded version of the London show is at the Guggenheim, and it's a stunner. Objects from pre-Aztec Mexico set the stage, but it is material from the bloody-minded, deity-besotted Aztec culture that fills the museum's darkened ramps. Set on jutting platforms and dark recesses are a skull-headed earth goddess in a skirt of writhing snakes, a warrior metamorphosing into a bird and a god of spring and fertility shedding his skin. Funky clay images of domestic life alternate with ultrasophisticated gold jewelry, and in one astonishing small sculpture, a human face splits apart to reveal the ages of man. The show may be a little too heavy on theater and too light on information, but it's totally mesmerizing. Hours: Saturdays through Wednesdays, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Fridays, 10 a.m. to 8 p.m. Admission: $18; $15, students and 65+.  HOLLAND COTTER    * 'COMIC GROTESQUE: WIT AND MOCKERY IN GERMAN ART, 1870-1940,' Neue Galerie, 1048 Fifth Avenue at 86th Street, (212) 628-6200, through Feb. 14. The horrors of World War I are usually credited with triggering the dark, often scathing humor that was used to comment on and combat some very unfunny developments in Germany in the first four decades of the century. But the Neue Galerie's splendidly multimedia revisionist show takes a broader view. It pinpoints paintings by Arnold Böcklin from the 1870's as a point of origin and then sweeps forward in a selective yet encompassing manner, touching on painting, poetry, graphic design and popular entertainment. It shows the influences of the satiric illustrator Thomas Theodor Heine on the mordant anti-Nazi montages of John Heartfield; places artists like Lionel Feininger and Alfred Kubin in context; and includes reconstructions of puppets made and used in performance by Heartfield, George Grosz and Hannah Höch. It culminates in the films of the great Karl Valentin, the star of stage, screen and cabaret who was Germany's Charlie Chaplin. Saturdays to Mondays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays, 11 a.m. to 9 p.m. Admission: $10; students and 65+, $7.  ROBERTA SMITH    'GREAT EXPECTATIONS: JOHN SINGER SARGENT PAINTING CHILDREN,' Brooklyn Museum, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000, through Jan. 16. Primarily known for his dashing portraits of high-born ladies sumptuously decked out, Sargent painted other subjects, too, not least among them children. And in these portraits, mostly of upper-class offspring, to be sure, he tended to get more real. This show, presenting about 40 works on the subject, has large ambitions. A major one is exploring how Sargent's likenesses tied in with the changing notions of childhood that came into play at the end of the 19th century, when children began to be regarded as distinctive personalities in their own right. For the most part here, he seems to see his young subjects that way, rather than as the syrupy stereotypes portrayed by his Victorian and 18th-century predecessors. Said to be the first exhibition to bring together Sargent's influential portraits of children, the show, with its catalog, is a refreshing new take on this bravura brushmeister. Hours: Wednesdays to Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. (to 11 p.m. on the first Saturday of every month). Admission: $8; students and 62+, $4.  GRACE GLUECK    * 'PRINCELY SPLENDOR: THE DRESDEN COURT, 1580-1620,' Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710, through Jan. 30. A densely baubled selection of some of the tools, armor, sculpture and bejeweled gewgaws that the princes of Dresden accumulated in the late 16th and early 17th centuries. Ignore the hackneyed and pompous exhibition title and consider this a constructive reminder of the artistic roots of wonderment. Besides ivory handled hammers, a 14-piece pocketknife, a mother-of-pearl cup in the shape of a parrot, silk doublets trimmed in silver and gold, a brass horn, and several automatons, which move about on hidden mechanized wheels, there is a portable hunting and writing desk. It is neatly stocked with gardening tools, writing and painting implements, cupping glasses, an oil cruet, soap boxes, scales, strainers, funnels, vintner's tools, barber's instruments, farrier's tools, locksmith tools -- in sum, the world, as a mirror of divine reason, a cabinet of wonders, for princes who had everything. Hours and admission: Sundays, Tuesdays through Thursdays, 9:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays until 9 p.m. Admission: $12; students and 65+, $7.  KIMMELMAN    'GILBERT STUART,' Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street (212) 535-7710, through Jan. 16. Known today mostly for his multiple images of George Washington, 14 of which are shown here, Stuart (1755-1828) painted many other faces, famous and not, as seen in this full-blown retrospective. Among them were Thomas Jefferson; John and Abigail Adams; the fur magnate John Jacob Astor; and countless British and American blueboods. Possessed of a penetrating talent augmented by a knowledge of physiognomy, Stuart apparently sussed out his subjects in lively conversation as he worked. The last Stuart retrospective was held nearly 40 years ago; this one reveals for a new generation that he was and remains one of our greatest American painters. Hours and admission: see above.  GLUECK    'TOTEMS TO TURQUOISE: NATIVE NORTH AMERICAN JEWELRY ARTS OF THE NORTHWEST AND SOUTHWEST,' American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West at 79th Street, (212) 769-5100, through July 10. Think of cave murals and Renaissance altarpieces used to contextualize examples of modern and contemporary painting and you've got the equivalent of this exhibition, a mixed bag of old and new, quality and special pleading. Here examples of jewelry and other small objects that date back to prehistoric times lend credence to late 20th and 21st century works that are sometimes little more than glitzy knockoffs. Enough recent efforts stand out to make the show a valuable essay on the very notion of traditions, how they are formed, perpetuated, renewed, exploited or exhausted. But claiming to follow the beliefs or crafts of one's ancestors does not guarantee a special purchase on spirituality. All art is essentially a faith-based initiative. Hours: Daily, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m. Admission: $13; children, $7.50; students and 62+, $10.  SMITH    Galleries: Uptown    'BOB THE ROMAN: HEROIC ANTIQUITY AND THE ARCHITECTURE OF ROBERT ADAM,' Gallery of the New York School of Interior Design, 161 East 69th Street, (212) 472-1500, through Dec. 4. Not for nothing did the Scotsman Robert Adam (1728-1792) playfully restyle himself ''Bob the Roman'' after soaking up the Eternal City on his youthful grand tour of Europe. Nearly everything he turned his hand to later as the celebrated architect, designer and interior decorator of late 18th-century England evoked the classical spirit of his beloved Rome. This show of more than 80 drawings made in the Adam office (Robert's brother, James, was his partner) is an enlightening introduction to the Adam brothers' scope. The works range from a nine-foot-long view of the facade of an intricate fantasy palace to numerous plans and proposals for town houses, villas and castles, along with their ornamentation, many of which actually got built. The show provides a fine glimpse of Robert Adam's role in helping to put an elegant and decorative new face on 18th-century English architecture.  GLUECK    GORDON COSTER, Keith de Lellis, 47 East 68th Street, (212) 327-1482, through Nov. 12. This retrospective exhibition of more than 60 photographs dating from 1925 to 1950 documents the career of a versatile and skillful photojournalist. It includes semi-abstract still-lifes and nudes, documentary pictures of inner city life and labor and civil rights strife and pictures of idyllic family scenes made for magazine ads that are, in some ways, among the show's most provocative images.  JOHNSON    ALFRED LESLIE: 'EXPRESSING THE ZEITGEIST,' Allan Stone Gallery, 113 East 90th Street, (212) 987-4997, through Dec. 22. Although thought of today primarily as a realist painter, Alfred Leslie started out as a second-generation Abstract Expressionist, a mover and shaker of the downtown world whose studio was a center of happenings and other events besides painting. This presentation of his vibrant early work from 1951 to 1962 ranges from tiny collages to large canvases, whose colors, chosen from a broad palette, were energetically laid on with heavy, loaded brushstrokes exuberantly accompanied by drips and spatter. They characteristically carry a pair or two of painted bars that punctuate the highly textured, often collaged surfaces like exclamation points.  GLUECK    * 'NEUE SACHLICHKEIT: NEW OBJECTIVITY IN WEIMAR GERMANY,' Ubu Gallery, 416 East 59th Street, (212) 753-4444, through Dec. 18. Heralded by the Expressionist Ludwig Meidner as a ''fanatical, fervent naturalism,'' the ostensibly realist style known as Neue Sachlichkeit was all that and more, as this uneven 80-work show vigorously suggests. It features the majestically factual photographs of August Sander, Karl Blossfeldt and Albert Renger-Patzsch, and works based on photographs by Georg Scholz, Eddy Smith and George Grosz that bring out reality's grotesque side. Carl Grossberg's pared-down, jewel-colored portrayals of German factories and villages evoke American Precisionism.  SMITH    Galleries: 57th Street    SAM CADY: 'MAINE, NEW PAINTINGS,' Mary Ryan Gallery 24 West 57th Street, (212) 397-0669, through Nov. 24. The state of Maine may have inspired more artists than any other in the Union, and here's another devoted example. In this group of mostly shaped canvases, closely tailored to fit the subjects, Mr. Cady celebrates the coastal village he lives in, where boats are built, fish are caught and seagulls clamor. But the painting is a little too slick to be all that down-homey.  GLUECK    TOMOKO SAWADA: 'COSTUME,' Zabriskie Gallery 41 East 57th Street, (212) 752-1224, through Nov. 13. In the tradition of Claude Cahun, Ana Mendieta and Cindy Sherman, the Japanese artist Tomoko Sawada puts female identity through its paces, but without limiting her role-playing to the studio. She enters the real world, to pose as a dentist, policewoman, secretary, nun, tea-house hostess in what might be called their natural habitats. What's most interesting is the way Ms. Sawada adjusts her facial expression and body language to each persona, and moreover to our preconceptions about the women's social status and psychological profile. The images need one another to be most effective, but in nearly every case, Ms. Sawada's performance is more than skin-deep, which is why it unsettles.  SMITH    DONALD SULTAN: 'NEW POPPY PAINTINGS,' Ameringer Yohe, 20 West 57th Street, (212) 445-0051, through Nov. 13. Mr. Sultan builds his massive pictures of flat, brightly colored poppy blossoms on velvety black fields out of industrial strength materials: plywood, masonite, linoleum, tar and enamel paint. Far from heavy-handed or over-bearing, however, his works exude a suave and seductive blend of visual and tactile sensuousness.  JOHNSON    WAYNE THIEBAUD, 'JUST DESSERTS,' Susan Sheehan, 20 West 57th Street, (212) 489-3331, through Dec. 18. No one did more to reanimate the tired old genre of still life painting in the last half century than did Mr. Thiebaud with his paintings of industrially regimented food products. His prints, sampled here in a 50-year retrospective, are less exciting than his paintings. Most are in black and white and on the small side. But they still convey the artist's wry vision of modern consumerism with forthright graphic efficiency, and the full-color prints of cans of paint, a row of lipsticks and a white rabbit are lovely.  JOHNSON    Galleries: SoHo    'THE ART OF READING,' Poets House, 72 Spring Street, (212) 431-7920, through Nov. 22. This appropriately quiet presentation of 38 small paintings, drawings, prints and photographs of people reading includes Paul Cadmus's portrait of Glenway Wescott; David Hockney's sweet colored pencil drawing of a young man reclining on a sofa; photographs of William S. Burroughs by Allen Ginsberg; and King Babar (the elephant) reading his newspaper at the beach in a watercolor by Laurent DeBrunhoff.  JOHNSON    Galleries: Chelsea    DONALD JUDD/ROBERT MANGOLD, PaceWildenstein, 534 West 25th Street, (212) 929-7000, through Nov. 13. The pairing of the paintings and sculptures of these major Minimalist artists is a no-brainer. But it looks surprisingly fresh and is beautifully installed. Each artist works with simple volumes of space, whether actual or illusionistic, that are divided and measured with the addition of repeating related elements. In Mr. Mangold's two or three lines undulate or curve from top to across the lightly gridded monochrome color-fields of his tall ''Column'' paintings. The divisions of Mr. Judd's boxed or columnar volumes of space proceed with perpendicular planes or repeating sometimes subdivided units. A large concrete floor piece with one-quarter of its interior sectioned is especially imposing in the way it complicates simplicity.  SMITH    JEFF LADOUCEUR: 'SCHMO,' ZieherSmith, 531 West 25th Street, (212) 229-1088, through Nov. 13. With a finely pointed pen in black ink and a meticulous touch, this Vancouver-based artist draws cartoons about a bald, long-nosed, sad sack of a character called ''Schmo.'' Our hero's struggles with ordinary existence and surrealistic encounters with cloud-creatures, tiny elephants, octopuses and an abominable snowman are funny, weird and touching.  JOHNSON    KURT LIGHTNER: 'A VIEW ALMOST PICTURESQUE,' Clementine, 526 West 26th Street, (212) 243-5937, through Nov. 13. A single huge and enthralling landscape occupies Clementine's main gallery. Measuring 12 by 22 feet, it presents a life-size, magically vivid squirrel's eye view into a forest. Part Pre-Raphaelite, part Charles Burchfield and part Walt Disney, it was made by gluing thousands of individual images of plants, trees, stones and ferns -- each painted in acrylic ink on Mylar -- onto big paper panels.  JOHNSON    VICTOR VASARELY: 'BLACK AND WHITE PAINTINGS FROM THE 1950'S,' Robert Miller, 524 West 26th Street, (212) 366-4774, through Nov. 13. This small but surprisingly interesting sideshow presents just six black and white paintings dating from 1952 to 1962. This Hungarian-born painter, who lived from 1906 to 1997, came to be thought of as a visual cheap trickster, but the optically tantalizing compositions of stripes, grid patterns and patterns like bar codes on view here have a fine, concentrated rigor.  JOHNSON    Other Galleries    'ELECTRIFYING ART: ATSUKO TANAKA, 1954-1968,' Grey Art Gallery, New York University, 100 Washington Square East, Greenwich Village, (212) 998-6780, through Dec. 11. In the late 1950's and early 1960's, Ms. Tanaka was a member of the avant-garde Japanese art group called Gutai, and the Grey Gallery survey covers the years of that association. It's a visually low-key show, but one with lots of ideas from an artist who was doing proto-Conceptualist and proto-Minimalist work and very early versions of sound and performance art. Spend time with the short films in the galleries; they bring everything else to life.  COTTER    * FREEDOM OF EXPRESSION NATIONAL MONUMENT, Foley Square, Lower Manhattan, (212) 206-6674, through Nov. 13. On a return engagement sponsored by Creative Time and the Lower Manhattan Cultural Council, this interactive outdoor sculpture, made in the symbolic year 1984, consists of a big, bright red Constructivist-style megaphone, through which members of the public can exercise their right to free speech. The work is a collaboration among the architect Laurie Hawkinson, the artist Erika Rothenberg and the performer John Malpede. It points, perhaps appropriately, toward the state and federal courthouses.  SMITH    'THE PRESIDENCY,' Exit Art, 475 10th Avenue, at 36th Street, (212) 966-7745, through Nov. 21. Among the few interesting pieces in this weak selection of politically tendentious works by 41 artists are Arbuzo Virtmanis's corrugated cardboard reconstruction of the president's bedroom on Air Force One; a deadpan video cartoon by Packard Jennings in which President Bush and members of his cabinet say things they would say if they were being completely honest; and an audio piece by 31 Down Radio Theater in which the president humbly apologizes for things he has done, from running for president to invading Iraq.  JOHNSON    SITE, Senior & Shopmaker, 21 East 26th Street, (212) 213-6767, through Dec. 4. A cool new addition to Madison Square Park is the ''Shake Shack,'' a fast-food kiosk designed by the architecture firm Sculpture in the Environment (SITE) that was founded in 1970 by James Wines. It is partly a postmodern hot dog stand, partly green architecture with its vegetation-covered roof and partly a way to generate revenue for the park. The small show of models and drawings at Senior & Shopmaker gives some background on this inventive and admirable effort to integrate form, function and environment.  JOHNSON    Last Chance    GEORGE CONDO, 'PAINTINGS FROM THE EIGHTIES,' Briggs Robinson, 527 West 29th Street, Chelsea, (212) 560-9075, through Nov. 9. Mr. Condo emerged in the context of the wildly subversive, early 80's East Village scene with his own painterly fusions of Pop, neo-expressionism, neo-surrealism and cartooning. With his images of clowns and goofy anthropomorphic animals, his inventive mimicry of artists like Picasso and Dalí and his insouciant play with abstraction, he lampooned high-culture pretentiousness while obliquely revealing a peculiarly emotional and anxious inner life. His paintings from the 80's are still funny, odd and affecting.  JOHNSON    'DON'T CALL IT PERFORMANCE,' Museo del Barrio, 1230 Fifth Avenue, at 104th Street, East Harlem, (212) 831-7272, through Sunday. Performative seems to be the preferred term now for performance art, to distinguish it from theater. Whatever, it's alive and kicking here, with short videos by 30 artists, mostly Latino or Latin American but including some North American and European colleagues, on view. The work is uneven, but you do get a sense that a younger generation is keeping performative work a vital presence in the art world. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission: $6; $4 for students and 65+.  GLUECK    GEORGE RICKEY, 'RETROSPECTIVE,' Maxwell Davidson, 724 Fifth Avenue, near 57th Street, (212) 759-7555, through tomorrow. Followers of Rickey's Modernist mobiles and whirly-gigs will enjoy this selection of small indoor works from five decades. Gently buffeted by electric fans set up in the gallery, elegantly composed and delicately balanced sets of metal blades, propellers, fins and panels move in slow, gracefully choreographed rhythms to soothing, hypnotic effect.  JOHNSON
